Is Teaching Girls How to Drill.

Sergeant Douglas Coulter is
ploying part of his mornings
by instructing a company of about
forty-five girls in setting-up exercises and military drill. His pupils are members of ,the New
School, 1104 North Charles street,
and are reported to be progressing with marvelous rapidity, being already proficient in the rudiments of training.

BELGIAN ARCHITECT LECTURES
Prof. Horta Addresses Archaeological
Society on "The Effects of War on
Buildings and Cathedrals of
Northern France."

Prof. Victor Horta, director of
the School of Fine Arts in Brussels, gave an illustrated lecture on
the effects of the war on Belgian
architecture in the Civil Engineering Lecture Hall on Thursday, November 1, under the auspices of
the Baltimore Society of the Archaeological Institute of America.
Dr. Robinson, professor of archaeology in the University and vicepresident of the archaeological society, presided at the meeting
which attracted a large gathering.
Dr. Robinson, in introducing
Professor Horta, explained that
the speaker was a practitioner as
well as a theorist. Not only has
Professor Horta for twenty years
been director of the School of Fine
Arts in Belgium, but also has been
a practical architect. At the time
of the German invasion in the
summer of 1914, Professor Horta
was supervising the construction
of a hospital in Tournai and a central railroad station in Brussels.
That the Germans appreciated his
ability in shown by the fact that
they allowed him to continue his
work after they occupied his country. The Belgian government appointed him in the early part of
1916 to study American architecture, since which time Professor
Horta has spent one year gazing—
with not too much admiration—at
New York skyscrapers. He is now
on a lecture tour that includes the
entire country.
Professor Horta named his lecture "The Cathedrals and Public
Buildings of Belgium and Northern France as Affected by the
War." He first described the character of the Walloon, Flemish and
Northern France countries. He
then gave a resume of the history
of the people and the expressions
of their art feelings in religious
and chil architecture. After
comparing the French and Belgian monuments in Rheims, Arras, Ypres, Tournai and Brussels,
he concluded his talk by summing
up what art has lost by the war
and telling what to do later with
the ruins for the benefit of art
and archaeology.
His lecture was supplemented
with slides of French cathedrals
and civil buildings throughout
Belgium. There was a pathetic
touch added when Professor Horta, whose life-work has been construction and art in contrast to
the German system of destruction
and savagery, told that he was
more affected by the destruction
of buildings than the slaughter of
Belgian men and soldiers, remarkfrig that they at least could fight
for themselves, whereas buildings
are absolutely defenseless.

ADVISES OBSERVANCE OF RULES;
JONES CAPTAIN OF 1921 ELEVEN

That all freshmen should exhibit
more spirit by attending football
games and mass-meetings was the
pith of President Carey's speech
to his classmates at the second
freshman meeting of the year on
last Monday in Gilman Hall.
In fulfillment of the object of
the meeting, Elmer Jones,'Varsity
halfback, was unanimously elected
captain of the freshman eleven.
He urged everyone to come out the
following Wednesday for practice.
Since a large proportion of the
'Varsity squad are freshmen, the
youngest class is confident of an
easy victory.
Burstein a former City College
debater, addressed the class in behalf of the freshman debating
team. He announced that all
those who were desirous of making
this team should prepare themselves on the subject of the freshman-sophomore debate. This subject will be decided on by Professor French and will be posted very
soon.

WORKS TO SPEED UP ATHLETICS FRESHIES AND SOPHS TO DEBATE
Mr. Kistler Tells Battalion Why Athletics
Are Slow—Men Must Get Together.
Will Start Company Competition
In All Sports.

Virginia and North Carolina Want Triangular Debate—Junior-Senior Tryouts Immediately—Fresh-Soph
Tryouts November 21.

Assistant Director of Athletics
Theodore Kistler said more about
the athletic situation at Hopkins
in ten minutes Thursday night
than the average Black and Blue
student thinks about them in his
entire college career. He was
standing on a table in the huge
Machinery Hall with the Hopkins
battalion drawn up before him at
attention. Some of the things
that Mr. Kistler told the men in
his genial way made them wince
and hurt all the more because they
were so patently true.
"Athletics at Homewood are far
too slow for me" was the manner
in which the diminutive instructor started out and before he had
gotten very far the old men in the
ranks knew that they were listening to an epoch-making speech as
far as the athletic future of the
University was concerned. In his
talk Mr. Kistler sketched briefly
the history of sports at Homewood
and analyzed the athletic problem.
He said that the greatest drawback that has always loomed up
has been the fact that the men
have never had a real opportunity
to know each other.
In order to reach the solution.
of this problem he has hit upon
a scheme of holding at least once a
month a battalion dance. But this
was probably the most modest of
his plans. He wants and is ready
to back to the last inch a friendly
spirit of athletic rivalry among
the three companies of the battalion. He wants three football teams
recruited from the ranks that will
strive for the gridiorn championship of the battalion. He does not
stop here, however. When the inclement weather drives the football
men to cover it is his purpose to
organize three basket-ball teams
from the companies to compete
for the basket-ball championship.
If his plans do not go amiss, the
companies will meet in swimming,
soccer and baseball and at the
end of the year the company that
has showed the greatest superiority in athletics will receive a
handsome trophy. These plans
are great in themselves, but the
significance that they carry with
them is more far-reaching than is
evident at first glance. When one
looks back at the various squads
of former years and then compares them with the number of
men that company rivalry is bound
to bring out for the five big sports,
it is not difftult to prophesy what
this event will mean to future
tears at Homewood. There are
thirty men working each day to get
a berth on the regular Black and
Blue football team and if Mr. Kistler's scheme does not go amiss
there will be forty-five other men
donning moleskins within the next
week. Just what this will mean

The Universities of North Carolina and Virginia have agreed to
resume the triangular debate, the
date of which will be announced
as soon as the arrangements, already under consideration, are
complete. The Debating Council
met on Thursday, November 1,
and discussed the question of a
subject for the debate. The Council
is anxious to select a subject that
will be of immediate and vital interest to the public and to college
men, and has under consideration
only up-to-date and living questions the final decision will be
made in the early part of this
week.
Tryouts for the senior and junior teams, which will debate the
same question, will be held before
the middle of this month. Men
who try out for these teams have
an excellent chance to make the
intercollegiate team, and it is
hoped that a large number of men
will avail themselves of this opportunity.
For the first time in the history
of Hopkins debating, the Council
has arranged a freshman-sophomore debate. The arrangements
for this debate are being made by
a committee made up of representatives of the two lower classes,
Charles Leber, of the Debating
Council, and Dr. French, debating
adviser. Tryouts will be held on
November 21, and the debate will
take place on January 5. Great
interest has been manifested by
both classes.
to the teams that are to fight for
Hopkins in the years to come is
almost inestimatable.
In addition to the unfolding of
these plans, Mr. Kistler made a
plea to the men to get behind the
efforts of the enthusiasts that are
working every minute to make
swimming and basket-ball recognized sports at the University.
The more sports we have the more
men will be benefited was the way
that Mr. Kistler expressed it and
from the applause that his remarks drew from the olive drab
ranks there is little doubt as to
the ultimate success of his plans.
After Mr. Kistler withdrew, Major Guild took the floor and pointed out the various advantages of
clean company rivalry. He said
that if a trophy can be given for
athletic supremacy among the
companies one should be given for
military excellence. He further
remarked that there was no man
more interested in the welfare of
the battalion than he, and that
when the time comes to measure up the respective abilities of
the different companies he can
promise that there will be a
trophy for the winning company.

Esprit de Corps.

Everything worth while has to
begin in a small way, has to pass
through gradual period of development, and has to be finally subjected to the combating powers of the
universe. As great oaks from little acorns grow, so must the Hopkins spirit now fostered by but a
few loyal men be nurtured and fed
until some day it will break forth
in devoted enthusiasm for our
Alma Mater, a something indefinable, intangible, yet vitally necessary in college life.
Last week two live-wire men told
us what they thought of our spirit,
and the way we support the institution. They endeavored to stimulate our enthusiasm, to kindle in
our breasts an unquenchable spark
of devotion to Hopkins—the kind
of devotion that rejoices in selfsacrifice. They tried, and will continue to try, to lead us from our
separate spheres of interest to one
world—the Hopkins world. They
want to mould us into a student
body with one mind, one ideal, one
spirit. Let no one think, however,
that in building up unity, they
want to tear down individualism.
Above all things they want the individual to stand out distinct on
the University horizon, but they
want him to submerge his selfish
interests in the common weal of
Johns Hopkins.
The commandant of the battalion and the assistant physical director want every member of the
University to be a little less conscious of self and a little more
conscious of the other fellow and
the college. They intend to build
up the Hopkins spirit, by first
nurturing it in the company, then
the battalion, then the University.

They are trying to knit the men
closer together, and stir up a spirit
• of pride in the company, the battalion, the University, and a spirit
of keen but friendly rivalry between its parts. They are introducing contests in athletics between companies and offering trophies. They want *the men to be
good sports as well as drillers.
When good sportsmanship is
evolved, the men will learn how to
sacrifice petty things for the good
of the battalion and University.
The constant competition will
stimulate always the desire to excel. And when this spirit of selfsacrifice is blended with the one
desire to 'excel, then will we have
a crack battalion, a live student
organism, in which every part is
loyally and whole-heartedly supported and in which every member
is striving for the good of Hopkins.
Wake Up, Upper classmen!

The sophomores may be regarded rather lightly by the upper
classmen, but it is admitted that
they put the juniors and seniors
to shame with their leading spirit
and attendance at the mass-meeting last Friday. If the upper
classmen wish to assert their
rights, now is the time. It is
hardly traditional for the sophomores to set an example for their
elders to follow.
Beat Western Maryland.

We have got to beat Western
Maryland. The time for pussyfooting and slacking has come to
an end, and every Hopkins man
has got to show his colors. Upon
the success of Saturday's game
depends our chances for the State
championship. Every one of us,
starting right now, has got to
w or k for that championship.
Those on the team have got to
fight harder than ever before, those
in the stands have got to yell
their lungs out. All this week and
at Friday's mass-meeting we have
got to stir up such a burst of enthusiasm that the visiting team
will be swept off the field. When
the first whistle blows that march
from. Gilman Hall to Homewood
Field has got to be a march of
coming victory.
The team and students now lack
punch. We have got to develop
that punch today, and hit the line
Saturday like a battering-rain.
Our goal is the State championship! We can get it if we start
fighting for it now. Beat Western
Maryland!
Princeton's Glee Club this year
will be organized on a different
basis than ever before. Instead
of the usual Easter trip, the purpose of the club this year will be
to provide entertainment for the
soldiers at the various national
encampments. Camp Dix, at
Wrightstown, N. J., will probably
be the scene of the greater part of
the activities of the Princeton students.—Ex.

Letters from Men in Service. 11
A holiday celebration at the
French front is vividly described
in the accompanying letter from
Henry C. Evans, lieutenant in the
U. S. light field artillery in
France, who before receiving his
commission served in the Convois
Automobiles, driving an ammunition truck. The scenes he portrays
are full of color, and are typical of
the brighter side of war life. More
letters from Evans will appear in
the future, permission having been
obtained from his parents to publish them. The letter is as follows:
CON'VOIS AUTOMOBILES, PARIS.
July 19, 1917.
DEAR FATHER:
We have been fairly busy lately,
although everyone grumbles about
the lack of excitement. We get
a German shell once in a while—
one landed about fifty feet from
me the other night, but that is
nothing compared to the dangers
of the real fighting. We all feel
that this is slackers work. The
United States papers seem to regard the ambulance and transport
divisions as slackers' jobs. They
are, but none of us came into this
with the idea of getting out of
danger and hard work we came
to get into it all the quicker. Most
of the fellows realize that this is
too easy a job for able-bodied men
and are going into something better. After seeing all the aeroplanes over here, we have all gone
crazy about aviation. I would
like to come back and go into the
U. S. aviation service, if I thought
I could get into it. Aviation will
win the war yet.
We had a great time on the
Fourth of July. There was a parade in -the morning and three
Frenchmen were presented with
"Croix de Guerre" medals. Then
we had all kinds of games, both
French and American, that last
most all day. Algerian bands
were here and they gave a concert
of their African and Arab music.
Then they did the crazy Arab and
Moroccan dances with swords and
rifles. It was hard to realize that
the scene was in France, to see all
the (lark Africans, some in turbans and others in red fezzes. The
(lay ended with fencing matches
between the French officers, and
then a banquet.
I have had almost every kind of
injection that they give now. I
had typhoid and paratyphoid before I left, and the other day they
gave me anti-tetanus serum to prevent lockjaw. I was in a collision
several nights ago in the dark and
got a small cut on my knee, so
they shot me full of anti-tetanus
serum. They do that over here if
you get cut at all, because there
is great danger of blood poison,
etc.
I have just received your letters
of the 29th of June and the 26th
of June.

FOOBALL REVIEW
By COACH BRENNICK
The game with Swarthmore on
Saturday brought to a close the
first phase of this year's football
season. During this period, with
one exception, admitedly superior
teams were met, and since we have
been less formidable than usual because of war conditions the results
in so far as victories are concerned
have not been altogther pleasing.
From the aspect of pure sport,
however, the results have been
most gratifying, for we have gotten together a group of men preponderatingly undergraduate who
play with a spirit and pluck that
has won admiration. The game
Saturday was a fair exhibition of
the physical capabilities of the
team when pitted against as heavy
and as skillful a team as Swarthmore, but it was not a fair showing of the team's mental ability,
for in this regard it was somewhat
off form. The team has not yet
learned, when working under the
pressure and stress of a game, how
to bring into execution the knowledge of the game it possesses. This
simply illustrates the often overlooked fact that there is a wide
gulf between knowing how to do a
thing and being able to do a thing.
Development in this direction has
been retarded by the experimenting in the quarterback position,
but Winslow has now demonstrated that he is capable of filling that
place in such a manner as to gain
the confidence of the team, a state
but just arrived at since Purcell's
injury.
The second phase of the season
begins this week and the first vital
test of the eleven against an opponent of equal strength takes
palce when we meet Western
Maryland Saturday next. This
team will come to Homewood with
its usual unbounded faith and confidence in its own ability backed
by exceptional skill on the part of
three or four players, so that if
we are to win we must be at the
top of our game and we must eradicate some glaring defects.
Our line at present is far ahead
of the backfield, both on offence
and defense, for the backfield thus
far failed to co-ordinate with the
line. On offence, the backfield,
except in spurts, has not shown
enough speed to take advantage
of the work of the line, while on
defense it has allowed plays which
have been checked by the forwards
or which have been stripped of
their interference, to develop from
losses into gains. Unless this error is corrected, victory is out of
the question. Our kicking game
must be improved also, for as it is
now, we are placed in jeopardy
every time we kick. It is needless
for us, we trust, to state that stern
endeavors will be made to wipe out
these deficiencies.

WILL EDIT 1918 HULLABALOO;
WHITEHEAD HON. PRESIDENT

After weighing carefully both
sides of the Hullabaloo question,
and considering a well drawn up
report submitted by an investigation committee, the Senior Class,
at a meeting held on October 30,
decided unanimously for the publication of a Hullabaloo. The decision was a popular one, for the
sentiment of the class had always
been to leave its record behind it
as former -classes had done; but
the choice was left unmade until
it was assured that financial success and literary talent were attainable.
The business of the meeting also
included the election of Major
Whitehead as honorary class
president, and of George S. Harris as class treasurer, to fill the
position left vacant by the withdrawal from the University of Ryland Dempster, who joined the
Naval Reserves.

HIGH TRIBUTE PAID TO PROFESSOR CLARKE

(Continuedfrom page I)

Professor Clarke. I first met him
in Berlin in the spring of 1887. He
Had just completed residence at
the University of Munich, where
he had won a doctor's degree. He
had just been asked by Prof.
George Williams then professor
of geology at Johns Hopkins University, to come to Baltimore as
instructor in geology; and he was
therefore deeply interested in
learning all he could about the
University, its spirit, its men and
the opportunities for work. I
wet him in Baltimore in the fall of
that year, and I remember well our
pleasant evenings together in his
rooms on Howard street, in the
oil University building which had
seen the construction of Rowland's
first engine and first concave grating spectroscope, and which was
torn down long ago to make room
for the present cage attached to
the gymnasium.
"The spirit he manifested in
that, his first, year, his attitude
towards his work and towards the
ideals of the University, his sympathy with the University with the•
being of the city and State, were
as marked then as on the last day
of his life • they never changed.
The controlling principle in his
life towards the University was
a firm realization of its duty to
foster and encourage individual
endeavors in all forms of research
and investigation. He inspired in
his colleagues and students a feeling of devotion to the purely scientific side of geology, as distinct
from that which may be called
its commercial side."
Dr. Ames' concluding words
were:"To him geology, and in fact
all sciences, were interesting, first
because their study contributed to
knowledge; but what was equally
important to him was the fact
that they also helped human endeavor. This recognition of the
two-fold aspect of scientific work,
in fact of all the activities of a
university, is not a common quality in the minds of most people;
the balance is not held so even."
Dr. Charles D. Wolcott, who before becoming secretary of the
Smithsonian Institution was director of the Geological Survey,
told of Dr. Clarke's achievements
as a geologist. "To estimate Dr.
Clarke's achievements," he said,
"we must consider the field of his
special work in the State of Maryland, where he began his activities
in.1888 and in 1896 organized the
State Geological Survey, and
again twenty-one years later when
his participation in the work was
suddenly brought to a close
through the tremendous strain
thrown on him by the war demands of his State and nation or
the organization on a war footing
of geological information of military value.
"In 1888 Dr. Clarke began a detailed study of the cretaceous and
tertiary formations of the Atlantic Costal Plain. So well did he

do his work that he became ge:
ologist in the U. S. Geological
Survey in 1894 and State Geologist in 1896. From the moment
he became State Geologist, Maryland began to grow steadily in the
geological scale and soon ranked
with Pennsylvania and New York
as one of the progressive states of
the Atlantic province. As a member of the U. S. Geological Survey
from 1888 to 1907, and as cooperating geologist during the
past ten years, he contributed to
the efficiency of that great national organization and always
held himself ready to render public service."
Judge Williams spoke on Professor Clarke's relations to the State
and its people. "No man has contributed more to the welfare and
wealth of Maryland," he said.
"Dr. Clarke opened the eyes of the
people of Maryland to its resources. It was remarkable that
he, a theorist, could impress his
views on the practical interest in
other things than geology. Dr.
Clarke had interest in other things
than geology. In 1893 he had a
bill put through to improve the
State highway, and for this he has
never received due credit. Since
1901 Professor Clarke has been
president of the Henry Watson
Children's Aid Society, and was
a delegate to the White House Conference called by President Roosevelt in 1909 to consider the subject of the dependent child. He
was also a member of the executive
committee of the State Tuberculosis Association and a vice-president and)chairman of the executive committee of the Federated
Charities of Baltimore."
In closing, Judge Williams gave
a quotation which he felt expressed
infinitely well the character of
Professor Clarke: "With all the
accomplishments of a gentleman,
he combined the virtues of a martry, and the piety of a Christian."
"Dr. Clarke laid deep and strong
foundations for the scientific and
economic survey of Maryland for
generations to come. When he began investigations, information as
'to the State's possible mineral resources, including water, was scattered unco-ordinated, and largely
inaccessible—the maps and reports
of the greatest value to all classes •
of intelligent citizens and to the
great economic interests of the
State and nation.
"Dr. Clarke made many contributions to geologic literature and
these contributions are available to
all. One of his monuments is the
series of reports of the State Survey, which compare favorably with
those of any State in the Union.
His achievements as a geologist
were fundamental and far reaching.
"His last labors in the study of
problems of national defense and
economic preparedness sailed for
all his ability as a geologist.
business man, humanitarian and
statesman. Here, as throughout
his life, he rose to the occasion and
realizing that mineral resources,

COMPANIES CLASH ON FRIDAY

STUDENT DOLLARS STILL UNPAID

Football Teams of A. and B Companies
to Stage Gridiron Battle—Trophies to
Be Awarded in Sports and
Military Efficiency.

Library Fund Otherwise Complete—Two
Allotments Oversubscribed—Undergraduate Subscriptions Wanted
at Once.

Mr. Kistler's plans for intercompany sports will be put into
practice this Friday when companies A and B will meet on the
gridiron. If Homewood Field cannot be used, the two teams will
clash on Straus Field, and start
the race for the battalion trophy,
which will probably be given to
the company winning the most
points in all the coming contests
in the schedule of sports now being arranged. Manager Jarrett,
of the football team, has agreed
to furnish the players with uniforms and all necessary material.
Companies A and C will play the
following Tuesday.
At the last Thursday drill, Major Guild announced that he intends to present at the end of the
year a silver cup to the company
which shall have reached the highest degree of military efficiency.
Many factors shall enter into consideration in the decision as to the
best company. Attendance, appearance and actual drill will
count, and the opinion of the Inspector General when he visits
Hopkins officially in the spring
will have an effect on the final decision. Every phase of drill, from
tactics to spirit, will be influential
in the choice.
His plans for a battalion flag
are not yet perfected. A design
for the flag and details for its
make-up have been completed, but
as yet no way has been found to
get the money necessary for the
purchase of the colors. A theatre
benefit for raising the money has
been suggested; and, while this
meets with the major's approval,
he is anxious for other suggestions.
The final step in completing the
personnel of the companies was
taken last week, when the corporals were appointed. Each company now, with its full quota of
officers, non-corns and privates, is
ready for the big winter drive.
Sergeant J. B. Eby was promoted to second leiutenant of Company A last Wednesday.

The results of the appeals made
at the mass-meeting of October 26
by Dr. Ames, chairman of the
War Library Council of Baltimore,
and Dr. Raney, secretary, for subscriptions to this fund are shown
in the fact that practically all who
had not contributed pledged a dollar. The sum from the Medical
School has nearly all been paid
and that from Goucher is entirely
complete, but the money from the
undergraduates is coming in very
slowly.
Of the four divisions of Hopkins' allotment of $2,000, two have
been over-subscribed; hence the
aim is not to collect a large sum
from each undergraduate, but to
have every man make a small contribution as soon as possible.
Those in charge of the Hopkins
campaign are anxious to close it
soon, for the national campaign is
at an end and another for books
is soon to be launched.
There is a possibility, if every
undergraduate gives something,
that each book bought with this
money will contain a printed plate
stating that the book was bought
with the contributions of Hopkins
men.

Dr. Clarke was born in Brattleboro, Vt., December 15, 1860. He
came of sterling ancestry. His
early education was pursued under private tutors, then at the
Brattleboro High School, where he
was graduated in 1879. Entering
Amherst College in 1880 he was
graduated with the degree of A.
B. in 1884. He immediately went
to Germany and pursued geological studies at Munich until 1887,
when he received the degree of Ph.
D. Before leaving Munich he was
appointed instructor in the Johns
Hopkins University.

SCHMIDT JUNIOR PRESIDENT;
'19 HULLABALOO INVESTIGATED

The juniors elected Carl W.
Schmidt president at the first
meeting of the class for this year,
and voted Theodore Chisolm vicepresident, John Frisch treasurer,
Malcolm Marty, secretary and
Stewart Hecht, sergeant-at-arms.
Baxley and Reed were elected delegates to the Student Council.
President Schmidt appointed a
committee to investigate the possibility of having a class Hullabaloo next year. He also urged the
juniors to get behind the Student
Council in enforcing the freshman
regulations.
TENORS WANTED FOR GLEE CLUB
BETTER ATTENDANCE NECESSARY

The regular rehearsal of the
Glee Club was held on last Thursday at 2115 North Charles street,
and was attended by comparatively few members. There was a noticeable lack of tenors, both first
and second, which makes the club
at present woefully unbalanced.
New music was gone over and
old numbers were rehearsed, but
there was a decided lack of the accustomed life and interest which
characterized the rehearsals of last
season.- Director Coulter has mentioned that the members do not
seem to realize that the musical
clubs are very essential parts of
student life as seen by outsiders,
and appeals to all who can sing to
come to the next rehearsal.

After holding an enthusiastic
organization meeting and securing
the endorsement of the Senior
Class, the men that are waging the
fight to put basket-ball on the
Black and Blue athletic map are
resting their case.
When the Athletic Board convenes some time this week, the
question of making the populor
winter sport a recognized one at
the University will be the allabsorbing topic, and when the
gymnasium history of the last few
years is scp.nned and the story of
the basket-ball successes that have
fallen to the lot of the Interclass
League and the Johns Hopkins Independents is retold it will be extremely hard for the powers that
be to say no.
The announcement that there
will be inter-company basket-ball
games throughout the year does
much to put the game on a firmer
basis. There are twenty men at
the University today with some
basket-ball experience and many
others that are willing to try their
hand at the game. With this as a
nucleus a quintet that will be a
distinct credit to the Black and
Blue can be built up with little
effort. Some of the best teams in
the East have expressed a keen desire to meet the Hopkins team if
they organize and if the athletic
bosses adhere to popular opinion
there will be many Saturday
nights of good sport for Hopkins
men during the winter.

Sir—It is a deplorable state of
affairs when a class, after passing
harmoniously through three years
of college life, breaks up into factions which oppose each other
upon no other grounds than departmental jealousy.
When the Class of 1918 entered
the University its spirit was conceded to be admirable. Its members obeyed the freshman regulations, at the same time maintaining an appearance of self-respect,
which won for them the esteem of
all the higher classes. In the second year of its existence,'18 handed down to the Hopkins men-to-be
an example of unforgetable cooperation and class spirit on the
memorable day of the sophomore
banquet. Last year it was again
1918 which, at a time when Hopkins football pessimism had dominated all else at the University,
came forth with a burst of the oldtime enthusiasm and "pep," which
carried the rest of the student
body in its grasp, and reawakened
the dormant Hopkins spirit.
And now, when the class should
be setting an example for the under classmen by continuing its old
"stick together" policy and by
striving, as one man, for all that
it, as a class, feels is loyal and
good—when it should endeavor to
command respect and admiration
more than ever before—it splits
into two parties. Why? Merely
because half the men are enrolled
in the academic department and
the other half ate engineers.
At an important class-meeting
held today, on every question but
one the engineering and academic
students were in solid opposition.
Instead of taking a stand which
they believed to be an honest one,
they "played politics." And this
is not the first time; for at previous class-meetings the same thing
has occurred. Are these the shining examples which should direct
the courses of the men who are
to mould the destiny of the Hopkins of the future?
Let every senior remember what
he stands for at the University;
let him strive to act as he knows
is the right and true course of action; so that when 1918 shall leave
Homewood behind it, the men who
follow it will have cause to say: Swarthmore

About fifteen out of the twentyfive men who signed up for track
have been taking training regularly
on the cross-country course and the
track around the Homewood field.
Coach England is very much disappointed because of the poor
showing, since Hopkins must be
represented by a good team in the
S. A. I. A. A. meet, to be held at
Homewood on the day of the St.
John's game, November 24, and in
the A. A. U. meet on Thanksgiving
Day, when the University meets
the Maryland Aggies on the gridiron. Plans for these are rapidly
being carried out.
The races, in which Hopkins
will compete with several of the
big colleges of the South will be
timed so that the finish will occur
in between the halves. Though he
wants men for cross-country work
especially, Coach England urges
those men who are interested in
track work other than cross-country to come out at once and get
into condition for the winter season.
Members of the Cross Country
Club of Baltimore are assisting the
coach in training the candidates
for the meets.
Several more candidates are
wanted for the position of assistant
manager. All interested are requested to give their names to
Manager Carroll.

BELGIAN ARCHITECT LECTURES
Prof. Horta Addresses Archaeological
Society on "The Effects of War on
Buildings and Cathedrals of
Northern France."

Prof. Victor Horta, director of
the School of Fine Arts in Brussels, gave an illustrated lecture on
the effects of the war on Belgian
architecture in the Civil Engineering Lecture Hall on Thursday, November 1, under the auspices of
the Baltimore Society of the Archaeological Institute of America.
Dr. Robinson, professor of archaeology in the University and vicepresident of the archaeological society, presided at the meeting
which attracted a large gathering.
Dr. Robinson, in introducing
Professor Horta, explained that
the speaker was a practitioner as
well as a theorist. Not only has
Professor Horta for twenty years
been director of the School of Fine
Arts in Belgium, but also has been
a practical architect. At the time
of the German invasion in the
summer of 1914, Professor Horta
was supervising the construction
of a hospital in Tournai and a central railroad station in Brussels.
That the Germans appreciated his
ability in shown by the fact that
they allowed him to continue his
work after they occupied his country. The Belgian government appointed him in the early part of
1916 to study American architecture, since which time Professor
Horta has spent one year gazing—
with not too much admiration—at
New York skyscrapers. He is now
on a lecture tour that includes the
entire country.
Professor Horta named his lecture "The Cathedrals and Public
Buildings of Belgium and Northern France as Affected by the
War." He first described the character of the Walloon, Flemish and
Northern France countries. He
then gave a resume of the history
of the people and the expressions
of their art feelings in religious
and chil architecture. After
comparing the French and Belgian monuments in Rheims, Arras, Ypres, Tournai and Brussels,
he concluded his talk by summing
up what art has lost by the war
and telling what to do later with
the ruins for the benefit of art
and archaeology.
His lecture was supplemented
with slides of French cathedrals
and civil buildings throughout
Belgium. There was a pathetic
touch added when Professor Horta, whose life-work has been construction and art in contrast to
the German system of destruction
and savagery, told that he was
more affected by the destruction
of buildings than the slaughter of
Belgian men and soldiers, remarkfrig that they at least could fight
for themselves, whereas buildings
are absolutely defenseless.

JONES CAPTAIN OF 1921 ELEVEN

That all freshmen should exhibit
more spirit by attending football
games and mass-meetings was the
pith of President Carey's speech
to his classmates at the second
freshman meeting of the year on
last Monday in Gilman Hall.
In fulfillment of the object of
the meeting, Elmer Jones,'Varsity
halfback, was unanimously elected
captain of the freshman eleven.
He urged everyone to come out the
following Wednesday for practice.
Since a large proportion of the
'Varsity squad are freshmen, the
youngest class is confident of an
easy victory.
Burstein a former City College
debater, addressed the class in behalf of the freshman debating
team. He announced that all
those who were desirous of making
this team should prepare themselves on the subject of the freshman-sophomore debate. This subject will be decided on by Professor French and will be posted very
soon.

WORKS TO SPEED UP ATHLETICS FRESHIES AND SOPHS TO DEBATE
Mr. Kistler Tells Battalion Why Athletics
Are Slow—Men Must Get Together.
Will Start Company Competition
In All Sports.

Virginia and North Carolina Want Triangular Debate—Junior-Senior Tryouts Immediately—Fresh-Soph
Tryouts November 21.

Assistant Director of Athletics
Theodore Kistler said more about
the athletic situation at Hopkins
in ten minutes Thursday night
than the average Black and Blue
student thinks about them in his
entire college career. He was
standing on a table in the huge
Machinery Hall with the Hopkins
battalion drawn up before him at
attention. Some of the things
that Mr. Kistler told the men in
his genial way made them wince
and hurt all the more because they
were so patently true.
"Athletics at Homewood are far
too slow for me" was the manner
in which the diminutive instructor started out and before he had
gotten very far the old men in the
ranks knew that they were listening to an epoch-making speech as
far as the athletic future of the
University was concerned. In his
talk Mr. Kistler sketched briefly
the history of sports at Homewood
and analyzed the athletic problem.
He said that the greatest drawback that has always loomed up
has been the fact that the men
have never had a real opportunity
to know each other.
In order to reach the solution.
of this problem he has hit upon
a scheme of holding at least once a
month a battalion dance. But this
was probably the most modest of
his plans. He wants and is ready
to back to the last inch a friendly
spirit of athletic rivalry among
the three companies of the battalion. He wants three football teams
recruited from the ranks that will
strive for the gridiorn championship of the battalion. He does not
stop here, however. When the inclement weather drives the football
men to cover it is his purpose to
organize three basket-ball teams
from the companies to compete
for the basket-ball championship.
If his plans do not go amiss, the
companies will meet in swimming,
soccer and baseball and at the
end of the year the company that
has showed the greatest superiority in athletics will receive a
handsome trophy. These plans
are great in themselves, but the
significance that they carry with
them is more far-reaching than is
evident at first glance. When one
looks back at the various squads
of former years and then compares them with the number of
men that company rivalry is bound
to bring out for the five big sports,
it is not difftult to prophesy what
this event will mean to future
tears at Homewood. There are
thirty men working each day to get
a berth on the regular Black and
Blue football team and if Mr. Kistler's scheme does not go amiss
there will be forty-five other men
donning moleskins within the next
week. Just what this will mean

The Universities of North Carolina and Virginia have agreed to
resume the triangular debate, the
date of which will be announced
as soon as the arrangements, already under consideration, are
complete. The Debating Council
met on Thursday, November 1,
and discussed the question of a
subject for the debate. The Council
is anxious to select a subject that
will be of immediate and vital interest to the public and to college
men, and has under consideration
only up-to-date and living questions the final decision will be
made in the early part of this
week.
Tryouts for the senior and junior teams, which will debate the
same question, will be held before
the middle of this month. Men
who try out for these teams have
an excellent chance to make the
intercollegiate team, and it is
hoped that a large number of men
will avail themselves of this opportunity.
For the first time in the history
of Hopkins debating, the Council
has arranged a freshman-sophomore debate. The arrangements
for this debate are being made by
a committee made up of representatives of the two lower classes,
Charles Leber, of the Debating
Council, and Dr. French, debating
adviser. Tryouts will be held on
November 21, and the debate will
take place on January 5. Great
interest has been manifested by
both classes.
to the teams that are to fight for
Hopkins in the years to come is
almost inestimatable.
In addition to the unfolding of
these plans, Mr. Kistler made a
plea to the men to get behind the
efforts of the enthusiasts that are
working every minute to make
swimming and basket-ball recognized sports at the University.
The more sports we have the more
men will be benefited was the way
that Mr. Kistler expressed it and
from the applause that his remarks drew from the olive drab
ranks there is little doubt as to
the ultimate success of his plans.
After Mr. Kistler withdrew, Major Guild took the floor and pointed out the various advantages of
clean company rivalry. He said
that if a trophy can be given for
athletic supremacy among the
companies one should be given for
military excellence. He further
remarked that there was no man
more interested in the welfare of
the battalion than he, and that
when the time comes to measure up the respective abilities of
the different companies he can
promise that there will be a
trophy for the winning company.

Esprit de Corps.

Everything worth while has to
begin in a small way, has to pass
through gradual period of development, and has to be finally subjected to the combating powers of the
universe. As great oaks from little acorns grow, so must the Hopkins spirit now fostered by but a
few loyal men be nurtured and fed
until some day it will break forth
in devoted enthusiasm for our
Alma Mater, a something indefinable, intangible, yet vitally necessary in college life.
Last week two live-wire men told
us what they thought of our spirit,
and the way we support the institution. They endeavored to stimulate our enthusiasm, to kindle in
our breasts an unquenchable spark
of devotion to Hopkins—the kind
of devotion that rejoices in selfsacrifice. They tried, and will continue to try, to lead us from our
separate spheres of interest to one
world—the Hopkins world. They
want to mould us into a student
body with one mind, one ideal, one
spirit. Let no one think, however,
that in building up unity, they
want to tear down individualism.
Above all things they want the individual to stand out distinct on
the University horizon, but they
want him to submerge his selfish
interests in the common weal of
Johns Hopkins.
The commandant of the battalion and the assistant physical director want every member of the
University to be a little less conscious of self and a little more
conscious of the other fellow and
the college. They intend to build
up the Hopkins spirit, by first
nurturing it in the company, then
the battalion, then the University.

They are trying to knit the men
closer together, and stir up a spirit
• of pride in the company, the battalion, the University, and a spirit
of keen but friendly rivalry between its parts. They are introducing contests in athletics between companies and offering trophies. They want *the men to be
good sports as well as drillers.
When good sportsmanship is
evolved, the men will learn how to
sacrifice petty things for the good
of the battalion and University.
The constant competition will
stimulate always the desire to excel. And when this spirit of selfsacrifice is blended with the one
desire to 'excel, then will we have
a crack battalion, a live student
organism, in which every part is
loyally and whole-heartedly supported and in which every member
is striving for the good of Hopkins.
Wake Up, Upper classmen!

The sophomores may be regarded rather lightly by the upper
classmen, but it is admitted that
they put the juniors and seniors
to shame with their leading spirit
and attendance at the mass-meeting last Friday. If the upper
classmen wish to assert their
rights, now is the time. It is
hardly traditional for the sophomores to set an example for their
elders to follow.
Beat Western Maryland.

We have got to beat Western
Maryland. The time for pussyfooting and slacking has come to
an end, and every Hopkins man
has got to show his colors. Upon
the success of Saturday's game
depends our chances for the State
championship. Every one of us,
starting right now, has got to
w or k for that championship.
Those on the team have got to
fight harder than ever before, those
in the stands have got to yell
their lungs out. All this week and
at Friday's mass-meeting we have
got to stir up such a burst of enthusiasm that the visiting team
will be swept off the field. When
the first whistle blows that march
from. Gilman Hall to Homewood
Field has got to be a march of
coming victory.
The team and students now lack
punch. We have got to develop
that punch today, and hit the line
Saturday like a battering-rain.
Our goal is the State championship! We can get it if we start
fighting for it now. Beat Western
Maryland!
Princeton's Glee Club this year
will be organized on a different
basis than ever before. Instead
of the usual Easter trip, the purpose of the club this year will be
to provide entertainment for the
soldiers at the various national
encampments. Camp Dix, at
Wrightstown, N. J., will probably
be the scene of the greater part of
the activities of the Princeton students.—Ex.

Letters from Men in Service. 11
A holiday celebration at the
French front is vividly described
in the accompanying letter from
Henry C. Evans, lieutenant in the
U. S. light field artillery in
France, who before receiving his
commission served in the Convois
Automobiles, driving an ammunition truck. The scenes he portrays
are full of color, and are typical of
the brighter side of war life. More
letters from Evans will appear in
the future, permission having been
obtained from his parents to publish them. The letter is as follows:
CON'VOIS AUTOMOBILES, PARIS.
July 19, 1917.
DEAR FATHER:
We have been fairly busy lately,
although everyone grumbles about
the lack of excitement. We get
a German shell once in a while—
one landed about fifty feet from
me the other night, but that is
nothing compared to the dangers
of the real fighting. We all feel
that this is slackers work. The
United States papers seem to regard the ambulance and transport
divisions as slackers' jobs. They
are, but none of us came into this
with the idea of getting out of
danger and hard work we came
to get into it all the quicker. Most
of the fellows realize that this is
too easy a job for able-bodied men
and are going into something better. After seeing all the aeroplanes over here, we have all gone
crazy about aviation. I would
like to come back and go into the
U. S. aviation service, if I thought
I could get into it. Aviation will
win the war yet.
We had a great time on the
Fourth of July. There was a parade in -the morning and three
Frenchmen were presented with
"Croix de Guerre" medals. Then
we had all kinds of games, both
French and American, that last
most all day. Algerian bands
were here and they gave a concert
of their African and Arab music.
Then they did the crazy Arab and
Moroccan dances with swords and
rifles. It was hard to realize that
the scene was in France, to see all
the (lark Africans, some in turbans and others in red fezzes. The
(lay ended with fencing matches
between the French officers, and
then a banquet.
I have had almost every kind of
injection that they give now. I
had typhoid and paratyphoid before I left, and the other day they
gave me anti-tetanus serum to prevent lockjaw. I was in a collision
several nights ago in the dark and
got a small cut on my knee, so
they shot me full of anti-tetanus
serum. They do that over here if
you get cut at all, because there
is great danger of blood poison,
etc.
I have just received your letters
of the 29th of June and the 26th
of June.

FOOBALL REVIEW
By COACH BRENNICK
The game with Swarthmore on
Saturday brought to a close the
first phase of this year's football
season. During this period, with
one exception, admitedly superior
teams were met, and since we have
been less formidable than usual because of war conditions the results
in so far as victories are concerned
have not been altogther pleasing.
From the aspect of pure sport,
however, the results have been
most gratifying, for we have gotten together a group of men preponderatingly undergraduate who
play with a spirit and pluck that
has won admiration. The game
Saturday was a fair exhibition of
the physical capabilities of the
team when pitted against as heavy
and as skillful a team as Swarthmore, but it was not a fair showing of the team's mental ability,
for in this regard it was somewhat
off form. The team has not yet
learned, when working under the
pressure and stress of a game, how
to bring into execution the knowledge of the game it possesses. This
simply illustrates the often overlooked fact that there is a wide
gulf between knowing how to do a
thing and being able to do a thing.
Development in this direction has
been retarded by the experimenting in the quarterback position,
but Winslow has now demonstrated that he is capable of filling that
place in such a manner as to gain
the confidence of the team, a state
but just arrived at since Purcell's
injury.
The second phase of the season
begins this week and the first vital
test of the eleven against an opponent of equal strength takes
palce when we meet Western
Maryland Saturday next. This
team will come to Homewood with
its usual unbounded faith and confidence in its own ability backed
by exceptional skill on the part of
three or four players, so that if
we are to win we must be at the
top of our game and we must eradicate some glaring defects.
Our line at present is far ahead
of the backfield, both on offence
and defense, for the backfield thus
far failed to co-ordinate with the
line. On offence, the backfield,
except in spurts, has not shown
enough speed to take advantage
of the work of the line, while on
defense it has allowed plays which
have been checked by the forwards
or which have been stripped of
their interference, to develop from
losses into gains. Unless this error is corrected, victory is out of
the question. Our kicking game
must be improved also, for as it is
now, we are placed in jeopardy
every time we kick. It is needless
for us, we trust, to state that stern
endeavors will be made to wipe out
these deficiencies.

WILL EDIT 1918 HULLABALOO;
WHITEHEAD HON. PRESIDENT

After weighing carefully both
sides of the Hullabaloo question,
and considering a well drawn up
report submitted by an investigation committee, the Senior Class,
at a meeting held on October 30,
decided unanimously for the publication of a Hullabaloo. The decision was a popular one, for the
sentiment of the class had always
been to leave its record behind it
as former -classes had done; but
the choice was left unmade until
it was assured that financial success and literary talent were attainable.
The business of the meeting also
included the election of Major
Whitehead as honorary class
president, and of George S. Harris as class treasurer, to fill the
position left vacant by the withdrawal from the University of Ryland Dempster, who joined the
Naval Reserves.

HIGH TRIBUTE PAID TO PROFESSOR CLARKE

(Continuedfrom page I)

Professor Clarke. I first met him
in Berlin in the spring of 1887. He
Had just completed residence at
the University of Munich, where
he had won a doctor's degree. He
had just been asked by Prof.
George Williams then professor
of geology at Johns Hopkins University, to come to Baltimore as
instructor in geology; and he was
therefore deeply interested in
learning all he could about the
University, its spirit, its men and
the opportunities for work. I
wet him in Baltimore in the fall of
that year, and I remember well our
pleasant evenings together in his
rooms on Howard street, in the
oil University building which had
seen the construction of Rowland's
first engine and first concave grating spectroscope, and which was
torn down long ago to make room
for the present cage attached to
the gymnasium.
"The spirit he manifested in
that, his first, year, his attitude
towards his work and towards the
ideals of the University, his sympathy with the University with the•
being of the city and State, were
as marked then as on the last day
of his life • they never changed.
The controlling principle in his
life towards the University was
a firm realization of its duty to
foster and encourage individual
endeavors in all forms of research
and investigation. He inspired in
his colleagues and students a feeling of devotion to the purely scientific side of geology, as distinct
from that which may be called
its commercial side."
Dr. Ames' concluding words
were:"To him geology, and in fact
all sciences, were interesting, first
because their study contributed to
knowledge; but what was equally
important to him was the fact
that they also helped human endeavor. This recognition of the
two-fold aspect of scientific work,
in fact of all the activities of a
university, is not a common quality in the minds of most people;
the balance is not held so even."
Dr. Charles D. Wolcott, who before becoming secretary of the
Smithsonian Institution was director of the Geological Survey,
told of Dr. Clarke's achievements
as a geologist. "To estimate Dr.
Clarke's achievements," he said,
"we must consider the field of his
special work in the State of Maryland, where he began his activities
in.1888 and in 1896 organized the
State Geological Survey, and
again twenty-one years later when
his participation in the work was
suddenly brought to a close
through the tremendous strain
thrown on him by the war demands of his State and nation or
the organization on a war footing
of geological information of military value.
"In 1888 Dr. Clarke began a detailed study of the cretaceous and
tertiary formations of the Atlantic Costal Plain. So well did he

do his work that he became ge:
ologist in the U. S. Geological
Survey in 1894 and State Geologist in 1896. From the moment
he became State Geologist, Maryland began to grow steadily in the
geological scale and soon ranked
with Pennsylvania and New York
as one of the progressive states of
the Atlantic province. As a member of the U. S. Geological Survey
from 1888 to 1907, and as cooperating geologist during the
past ten years, he contributed to
the efficiency of that great national organization and always
held himself ready to render public service."
Judge Williams spoke on Professor Clarke's relations to the State
and its people. "No man has contributed more to the welfare and
wealth of Maryland," he said.
"Dr. Clarke opened the eyes of the
people of Maryland to its resources. It was remarkable that
he, a theorist, could impress his
views on the practical interest in
other things than geology. Dr.
Clarke had interest in other things
than geology. In 1893 he had a
bill put through to improve the
State highway, and for this he has
never received due credit. Since
1901 Professor Clarke has been
president of the Henry Watson
Children's Aid Society, and was
a delegate to the White House Conference called by President Roosevelt in 1909 to consider the subject of the dependent child. He
was also a member of the executive
committee of the State Tuberculosis Association and a vice-president and)chairman of the executive committee of the Federated
Charities of Baltimore."
In closing, Judge Williams gave
a quotation which he felt expressed
infinitely well the character of
Professor Clarke: "With all the
accomplishments of a gentleman,
he combined the virtues of a martry, and the piety of a Christian."
"Dr. Clarke laid deep and strong
foundations for the scientific and
economic survey of Maryland for
generations to come. When he began investigations, information as
'to the State's possible mineral resources, including water, was scattered unco-ordinated, and largely
inaccessible—the maps and reports
of the greatest value to all classes •
of intelligent citizens and to the
great economic interests of the
State and nation.
"Dr. Clarke made many contributions to geologic literature and
these contributions are available to
all. One of his monuments is the
series of reports of the State Survey, which compare favorably with
those of any State in the Union.
His achievements as a geologist
were fundamental and far reaching.
"His last labors in the study of
problems of national defense and
economic preparedness sailed for
all his ability as a geologist.
business man, humanitarian and
statesman. Here, as throughout
his life, he rose to the occasion and
realizing that mineral resources,

STUDENT DOLLARS STILL UNPAID

Football Teams of A. and B Companies
to Stage Gridiron Battle—Trophies to
Be Awarded in Sports and
Military Efficiency.

Library Fund Otherwise Complete—Two
Allotments Oversubscribed—Undergraduate Subscriptions Wanted
at Once.

Mr. Kistler's plans for intercompany sports will be put into
practice this Friday when companies A and B will meet on the
gridiron. If Homewood Field cannot be used, the two teams will
clash on Straus Field, and start
the race for the battalion trophy,
which will probably be given to
the company winning the most
points in all the coming contests
in the schedule of sports now being arranged. Manager Jarrett,
of the football team, has agreed
to furnish the players with uniforms and all necessary material.
Companies A and C will play the
following Tuesday.
At the last Thursday drill, Major Guild announced that he intends to present at the end of the
year a silver cup to the company
which shall have reached the highest degree of military efficiency.
Many factors shall enter into consideration in the decision as to the
best company. Attendance, appearance and actual drill will
count, and the opinion of the Inspector General when he visits
Hopkins officially in the spring
will have an effect on the final decision. Every phase of drill, from
tactics to spirit, will be influential
in the choice.
His plans for a battalion flag
are not yet perfected. A design
for the flag and details for its
make-up have been completed, but
as yet no way has been found to
get the money necessary for the
purchase of the colors. A theatre
benefit for raising the money has
been suggested; and, while this
meets with the major's approval,
he is anxious for other suggestions.
The final step in completing the
personnel of the companies was
taken last week, when the corporals were appointed. Each company now, with its full quota of
officers, non-corns and privates, is
ready for the big winter drive.
Sergeant J. B. Eby was promoted to second leiutenant of Company A last Wednesday.

The results of the appeals made
at the mass-meeting of October 26
by Dr. Ames, chairman of the
War Library Council of Baltimore,
and Dr. Raney, secretary, for subscriptions to this fund are shown
in the fact that practically all who
had not contributed pledged a dollar. The sum from the Medical
School has nearly all been paid
and that from Goucher is entirely
complete, but the money from the
undergraduates is coming in very
slowly.
Of the four divisions of Hopkins' allotment of $2,000, two have
been over-subscribed; hence the
aim is not to collect a large sum
from each undergraduate, but to
have every man make a small contribution as soon as possible.
Those in charge of the Hopkins
campaign are anxious to close it
soon, for the national campaign is
at an end and another for books
is soon to be launched.
There is a possibility, if every
undergraduate gives something,
that each book bought with this
money will contain a printed plate
stating that the book was bought
with the contributions of Hopkins
men.

Dr. Clarke was born in Brattleboro, Vt., December 15, 1860. He
came of sterling ancestry. His
early education was pursued under private tutors, then at the
Brattleboro High School, where he
was graduated in 1879. Entering
Amherst College in 1880 he was
graduated with the degree of A.
B. in 1884. He immediately went
to Germany and pursued geological studies at Munich until 1887,
when he received the degree of Ph.
D. Before leaving Munich he was
appointed instructor in the Johns
Hopkins University.

SCHMIDT JUNIOR PRESIDENT;
'19 HULLABALOO INVESTIGATED

The juniors elected Carl W.
Schmidt president at the first
meeting of the class for this year,
and voted Theodore Chisolm vicepresident, John Frisch treasurer,
Malcolm Marty, secretary and
Stewart Hecht, sergeant-at-arms.
Baxley and Reed were elected delegates to the Student Council.
President Schmidt appointed a
committee to investigate the possibility of having a class Hullabaloo next year. He also urged the
juniors to get behind the Student
Council in enforcing the freshman
regulations.
TENORS WANTED FOR GLEE CLUB
BETTER ATTENDANCE NECESSARY

The regular rehearsal of the
Glee Club was held on last Thursday at 2115 North Charles street,
and was attended by comparatively few members. There was a noticeable lack of tenors, both first
and second, which makes the club
at present woefully unbalanced.
New music was gone over and
old numbers were rehearsed, but
there was a decided lack of the accustomed life and interest which
characterized the rehearsals of last
season.- Director Coulter has mentioned that the members do not
seem to realize that the musical
clubs are very essential parts of
student life as seen by outsiders,
and appeals to all who can sing to
come to the next rehearsal.

After holding an enthusiastic
organization meeting and securing
the endorsement of the Senior
Class, the men that are waging the
fight to put basket-ball on the
Black and Blue athletic map are
resting their case.
When the Athletic Board convenes some time this week, the
question of making the populor
winter sport a recognized one at
the University will be the allabsorbing topic, and when the
gymnasium history of the last few
years is scp.nned and the story of
the basket-ball successes that have
fallen to the lot of the Interclass
League and the Johns Hopkins Independents is retold it will be extremely hard for the powers that
be to say no.
The announcement that there
will be inter-company basket-ball
games throughout the year does
much to put the game on a firmer
basis. There are twenty men at
the University today with some
basket-ball experience and many
others that are willing to try their
hand at the game. With this as a
nucleus a quintet that will be a
distinct credit to the Black and
Blue can be built up with little
effort. Some of the best teams in
the East have expressed a keen desire to meet the Hopkins team if
they organize and if the athletic
bosses adhere to popular opinion
there will be many Saturday
nights of good sport for Hopkins
men during the winter.

Sir—It is a deplorable state of
affairs when a class, after passing
harmoniously through three years
of college life, breaks up into factions which oppose each other
upon no other grounds than departmental jealousy.
When the Class of 1918 entered
the University its spirit was conceded to be admirable. Its members obeyed the freshman regulations, at the same time maintaining an appearance of self-respect,
which won for them the esteem of
all the higher classes. In the second year of its existence,'18 handed down to the Hopkins men-to-be
an example of unforgetable cooperation and class spirit on the
memorable day of the sophomore
banquet. Last year it was again
1918 which, at a time when Hopkins football pessimism had dominated all else at the University,
came forth with a burst of the oldtime enthusiasm and "pep," which
carried the rest of the student
body in its grasp, and reawakened
the dormant Hopkins spirit.
And now, when the class should
be setting an example for the under classmen by continuing its old
"stick together" policy and by
striving, as one man, for all that
it, as a class, feels is loyal and
good—when it should endeavor to
command respect and admiration
more than ever before—it splits
into two parties. Why? Merely
because half the men are enrolled
in the academic department and
the other half ate engineers.
At an important class-meeting
held today, on every question but
one the engineering and academic
students were in solid opposition.
Instead of taking a stand which
they believed to be an honest one,
they "played politics." And this
is not the first time; for at previous class-meetings the same thing
has occurred. Are these the shining examples which should direct
the courses of the men who are
to mould the destiny of the Hopkins of the future?
Let every senior remember what
he stands for at the University;
let him strive to act as he knows
is the right and true course of action; so that when 1918 shall leave
Homewood behind it, the men who
follow it will have cause to say: Swarthmore

About fifteen out of the twentyfive men who signed up for track
have been taking training regularly
on the cross-country course and the
track around the Homewood field.
Coach England is very much disappointed because of the poor
showing, since Hopkins must be
represented by a good team in the
S. A. I. A. A. meet, to be held at
Homewood on the day of the St.
John's game, November 24, and in
the A. A. U. meet on Thanksgiving
Day, when the University meets
the Maryland Aggies on the gridiron. Plans for these are rapidly
being carried out.
The races, in which Hopkins
will compete with several of the
big colleges of the South will be
timed so that the finish will occur
in between the halves. Though he
wants men for cross-country work
especially, Coach England urges
those men who are interested in
track work other than cross-country to come out at once and get
into condition for the winter season.
Members of the Cross Country
Club of Baltimore are assisting the
coach in training the candidates
for the meets.
Several more candidates are
wanted for the position of assistant
manager. All interested are requested to give their names to
Manager Carroll.
